G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Jessica Taylor, and pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related provisions, respectfully petitions this Honorable Court to modify the existing custody and visitation order entered on **March 15, 2021**, on the grounds that there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** affecting the best interests of the minor child, **Sophie Davis (age 8)**.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 10\u201311.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10–11**, and **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as this Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and visitation matters concerning the minor child.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10–11**, and **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as this Court retains continuing jurisdiction over custody and visitation matters concerning the minor child.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223A, \u00a7\u00a7 2.proposition: Venue lies in this Court pursuant to **Mass. Prob. Ct. Standing Order 1-04** and **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223A, §§ 2–3**, as the original order was issued here and Plaintiff and the child reside within the Middlesex Division.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28** and **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or visitation order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and a finding that modification serves the child’s best interests.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that a **parent’s relocation or significant change in living circumstances** constitutes a material change justifying modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the substantive standard for allowing or denying a custodial parent’s request to relocate with children under G.L. c. 208, § 30, where there is joint legal and physical custody. It does not address modification standards or characterize relocation as a “material change” justifying modification of an existing custody order. The discussion of relocation as a “substantial change in circumstances” appears only in a quotation from the ALI Principles, not as a Massachusetts holding about material change for modification purposes, so it does not support the proposition claimed.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce]….’”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that a **parent’s relocation or significant change in living circumstances** constitutes a material change justifying modification.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and child-support case; it does not discuss the general standard for modification based on a material change in circumstances in the sense of relocation or altered living circumstances. The only explicit reference to material and substantial change concerns the mother’s remarriage as alleged grounds to modify child support, not custody or parenting orders, and the court does not state or reaffirm any broad rule that relocation or significant living-changes, as such, constitute a material change justifying modification. Thus it does not support the proposition cited.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “In support of his complaint for modification, the father alleged as a material and substantial change of circumstances the mother’s remarriage. At the time of the modification trial, the judge found that the father’s income had modestly increased, and that the mother’s income remained at zero. The judge further found, however, that the mother now receives estimated contributions from her new husband in the amount of $1,000 per week.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The standard of review focuses on **the best interests of the child**, as reaffirmed in **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); and **Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that under the removal statute the standard is whether removal is in the “best interests of the child,” and then elaborates how those best interests are to be evaluated. Although Yannas refines this through the ‘real advantage’ framework in relocation cases, it repeatedly reaffirms that the paramount standard is the child’s best interests, making it proper authority for the proposition that the governing standard of review focuses on the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The standard of review focuses on **the best interests of the child**, as reaffirmed in **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); and **Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames both the custody-modification and removal analyses in terms of the child’s best interests, expressly tying the removal standard to Yannas and its best-interest framework. The court quotes Yannas on the primacy of the child’s best interests and applies that standard to evaluate whether removal and custody modification are appropriate, confirming that the governing standard of review is the best interests of the child. Thus, Rosenthal v. Maney supports the proposition that the standard focuses on the child’s best interests, as articulated in Yannas and later cases.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today…is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’). … A request for removal is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30, as that statute has been interpreted by Yannas… ‘Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern….’”}

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The standard of review focuses on **the best interests of the child**, as reaffirmed in **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); and **Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015).
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly identifies the governing removal standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 as requiring that removal be in the best interests of the child, and it does so by citing and applying Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas. It further explains the two‑stage Yannas analysis and reiterates that, even under the real‑advantage framework, the ultimate inquiry is whether removal serves the child’s best interests. Thus, Schechter squarely reaffirms that the controlling standard of review in removal cases is the best interests of the child, consistent with Yannas (and by extension Rosenthal).
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A request for removal is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30, which states that … [t]he statutory standard of ‘upon cause shown’ means that removal must be in the best interests of the child. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985). … We recently explained that the real advantage test does not mean that so long as the custodial parent is advantaged by a move to another State, a judge is required to approve the request. … Ultimately, the judge must determine that removal is in the best interests of the child.”

Miller v. Miller, 478 Mass. 642 (2018).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that substantial increases in travel burdens or disruption of school or activity schedules may constitute a material change.

Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that substantial increases in travel burdens or disruption of school or activity schedules may constitute a material change.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion is about relocation standards under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the interaction with a surviving separation agreement. It discusses the ‘real advantage’ and best-interests tests, not what constitutes a ‘material change’ in circumstances. There is no analysis that substantial increases in travel burdens or disruption of school or activity schedules amount to a material change; “material change” is mentioned only in describing the higher ‘countervailing equities’ standard, without elaboration on travel or scheduling impacts.
Williams v. Pitney, 409 Mass. 449 (1991).relevant_excerpt: The father... argues that the judge should have required the mother to show “something more than a material change of circumstances,” or the so-called “countervailing equities” standard, in order to modify the provision of the agreement. See Stansel, supra at 515 (where parties have entered into separation agreement that was fair, reasonable, not the product of fraud or coercion, and survives the judgment, more than a material change of circumstances must be shown before the judge refuses to enforce it).

Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 772 (2006)
Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that substantial increases in travel burdens or disruption of school or activity schedules may constitute a material change.
Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation request and applies the Yannas ‘real advantage’ and best-interest tests; it does not address modification standards or what constitutes a ‘material change’ in circumstances. While the decision acknowledges that relocation affects visitation and the parent-child relationship, it does not discuss substantial increases in travel burdens or disruption of school/activities as a ‘material change’ for purposes of modifying an existing order. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Wakefield v. Hegarty, 67 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The purpose of the statute is to preserve the rights of the noncustodial parent and the child to maintain and develop their familial relationships, while balancing those rights with the right of the custodial parent to seek a better life for himself or herself in another State or country. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 712 (1985). … The judge, in arriving at her decision, took into consideration the preservation of the child’s relationship with the father. … [V]isitation by the father will change to his disadvantage, but … the alternative visitation arrangements were reasonable.”}

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The child’s welfare must predominate over parental convenience or parental rights.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly characterizes the governing standard in custody disputes as the child’s welfare and best interests being the “paramount” or “most fundamental” concern, rather than parental claims. The court explains that custody decisions should not seek to optimize parental preferences but must prioritize stability, continuity of care, and what arrangement best serves the child, even over a parent’s asserted entitlement to custody. This aligns with the proposition that the child’s welfare predominates over parental convenience or parental rights.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… This legal principle replaced the notion that children were the property of their parents, and instructed courts to view children as individuals with interests independent of their parents… the ‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’ … ‘the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.’”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The child’s welfare must predominate over parental convenience or parental rights.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that in custody determinations the governing and dominating principle is the welfare of the child, and that parental wishes are secondary. By affirming a custody award based on this standard and quoting prior cases emphasizing that the child’s welfare is the controlling consideration over parental interests, the case supports the proposition that the child’s welfare must predominate over parental convenience or rights.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Continuing the midweek overnight would cause undue hardship and stress for the child due to extended commutes and interference with her school and extracurricular schedule—factors courts consider central to the best interests analysis.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation and the mother’s unilateral right to relocate prior to adjudication of paternity. It does not discuss midweek overnights, commuting burdens, school or extracurricular schedules, nor does it identify those logistical stresses as central factors in a best‑interests analysis. Instead, it criticizes the trial judge for improperly applying a removal framework and emphasizes stability and the statutory custody scheme, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. … Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Continuing the midweek overnight would cause undue hardship and stress for the child due to extended commutes and interference with her school and extracurricular schedule—factors courts consider central to the best interests analysis.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with removal of children from Massachusetts and the factors relevant to a best-interests analysis in that context, focusing on the welfare of the custodial parent, the children’s relationship with the noncustodial parent, alternative visitation, and the children’s preferences. It does not discuss midweek overnights, commuting burdens, or interference with school and extracurricular activities as specific factors, nor does it frame such logistical hardships as central to the best-interests analysis. The proposition therefore overreads the case and attributes to it a consideration that is not present in the opinion.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice… on the parent having the primary responsibility for the day-to-day care of the children.”
